unit: Unit 1: A Visit to the La Tree Farm
question: Where is the La Tree Farm located?A) KaohsiungB) Donghe, TaiTungC) HsinChuD) Taipei
How old was Lily during her first visit to the farm?A) TenB) TwelveC) TwentyD) Fifteen
What does "action" describe regarding the workers?A) They were busy working in the fieldB) They were watching a movieC) They were resting in their roomsD) They were driving to the city
What color was the soil on the farm?A) RedB) GreyC) BrownD) Black
Why did Lily have an "idea"?A) She wanted to buy the farmB) She wanted to sell her cameraC) She wanted to leave earlyD) She wanted to explore every corner and study the trees
What was the guide's first act of "welcome"?A) Giving Lily a cameraB) Handing her a card with a mapC) Offering her a glass of waterD) Singing a song
How many bananas did Lily eat in total?A) TwoB) OneC) ThreeD) None
In the sentence "the soil was... making it the perfect place," what does "making" mean?A) Building a structureB) Cooking foodC) Causing it to beD) Fixing a tool

Why did Lily start "timing" at the end of the visit?A) She was measuring her running speedB) She was checking the car's speedC) She was timing her camera shutterD) She was counting down to their next visit
What was Lily "amazed" by according to the text?A) The large number of treesB) The size of the guideC) The price of the bananasD) The height of the room
What was Lily's emotional state when leaving the farm?A) AngerB) SatisfactionC) SadnessD) Boredom
What song was "radioed" during the return trip?A) Happy TreeB) Sunshine DayC) Lemon TreeD) Ocean Breeze
Which month did the visit take place?A) MayB) MarchC) JuneD) August
What does the term "outside" describe in the first paragraph?A) The interior of the carB) The area beyond the roomC) The center of the cityD) The top of a tree
The "timing" of the weather during the afternoon was:A) RainyB) SunnyC) ColdD) Cloudy
What did Lily do with her camera?A) She lost it in the fieldB) She gave it to her parentsC) She took many shots of the treesD) She used it to study maps
What did the guide's "handing" a second banana signify?A) Hospitality and a warm welcomeB) He was tired of holding itC) It was part of a tradeD) He was in a hurry
What "question" did Lily have during the journey?A) How long the drive wasB) How the trees were planted and grownC) Where the sea was D) What the guide's name was

What was the "So What?" (strategic outcome) of this visit for Lily?A) She decided to become a guideB) She wanted to move to DongheC) It sparked a lifelong love for natureD) She learned how to grow bananas
The air at the farm was described as being filled with:A) Smoke from the fieldB) The scent of bananasC) The salty scent of the seaD) The smell of fresh soil

unit: Unit 2: A Story behind a Haircut
question: What was Jake's "strong" trait?A) MusclesB) VoiceC) Character D) Knowledge
How many people were waiting before Jake?A) NineB) FifteenC) OneD) Twenty
Where did Jake sit while waiting?A) In the carB) Outside the shopC) On the chair beside a plantD) On the floor
What was Jake's passion?A) GardeningB) AnimalsC) MusicD) Painting
Why did Jake choose the local shop in town?A) It was the most famousB) It was owned by his relativeC) He liked the plants thereD) It didn't cost too much
What did the receptionist "ticket" to Jake?A) A coupon for a future visitB) A slip of paper showing his turnC) A map of the townD) A business card
How did the scissors "sound" to Jake?A) Like musicB) Like a fightC) Like a birdD) Like a radio
What "begin" describes the barber's action?A) He began to sleepB) He began to work his magicC) He began to singD) He began to cook
What happened right before the "finish" of the haircut?A) Jake fell off the chairB) The barber stopped to drink sodaC) The barber accidentally touched Jake's ear with the scissorsD) The shop closed
Why did Jake avoid "fighting" with the barber after the mistake?A) He was showing empathy and kindnessB) He didn't feel any painC) He was afraid of the barberD) He was in a rush to get home
How much experience did the barber have?A) Ten yearsB) It was his first dayC) He was a masterD) He had only nine months of training
What did the barber give Jake to show he was sorry?A) A free plantB) A ticket for a raceC) A bottle of sodaD) A new pair of scissors
What did the barber promise to "mail" to Jake?A) Some couponsB) A photo of the shopC) A letter from the townD) A new hairstyle map
What did Jake say about the barber's "level"?A) It was already perfectB) It would get higher with practiceC) It was lower than the receptionist'sD) It was at its finish
How did Jake feel as he headed "home"?A) Sad and hurtB) Angry at the costC) Bored of the townD) Happy, as if he won the world
Where was the barber shop located?A) In HsinChu city centerB) In the township of XinfengC) Near a zooD) On a farm
The word "almost" describes his hair length. How long was it?A) Down to his shouldersB) Short and trendyC) Up to his noseD) Nine inches long
What did the barber do for the "last touches"?A) He washed Jake's hairB) He finished the haircut with more careC) He painted the wallsD) He looked in the mirror
Jake's dream job was to be a:A) BarberB) TeacherC) FarmerD) Veterinarian

What is the "So What?" (message) of Jake's reaction to the injury?A) First days are always badB) Empathy can turn a mistake into a positive interactionC) Barber shops in town are dangerousD) It is better to cut your own hair

unit: Unit 3: A Journey to Health and Happiness
question: On what day did the narrator visit the doctor?A) WednesdayB) MondayC) FridayD) Sunday
What color was the sweater the narrator wore?A) BrownB) YellowC) GreenD) Red
What did the nurse "pencil" down?A) A recipe for medicineB) Information on a piece of paperC) The name of a frogD) The price of the examination
Where was the narrator asked to stay?A) Outside in the carB) Inside the waiting roomC) On the seesawD) At home
What animals were featured in the TV documentary?A) Lions, elephants, and cowboysB) Frogs and ducksC) Cats and dogsD) Birds and mice
Which animal made the narrator "laugh"?A) A lionB) A frog on the floorC) A cow in a fieldD) A kitten in the park
What were children doing "outside" of the waiting room?A) Sleeping and restingB) Painting, playing with sand, and on the seesawC) Taking an examinationD) Eating bananas
What was the little girl doing "right" in the corner?A) Reading a newspaperB) Painting a sceneC) Playing the pianoD) Feeding a dog
What did the doctor tell the narrator to "except" from the daily schedule?A) SleepB) RestC) WorkD) Eating
How often must the narrator take the medicine?A) Every WednesdayB) Every dayC) Every second hourD) Only once
When should the narrator return for a "second" examination?A) TomorrowB) YesterdayC) Next weekD) Never

What was the "So What?" (message) of the story's conclusion?A) Working hard is the only path to successB) Success requires a strong will but cannot work without good healthC) Doctors are glad to see patients on WednesdaysD) Playing the piano helps you feel well
What does "still" mean in "Sitting still, I enjoyed..."?A) Quiet and motionlessB) Moving fastC) Standing upD) Loudly
How did the narrator feel about the appointment?A) AngryB) GladC) SadD) Bored
What did the narrator wear to stay "warm"?A) A yellow sweater and scarfB) A brown coat and hatC) A green jacket and glovesD) A suit and tie
The narrator realized it had been a long time since:A) He was a childB) He saw a frogC) He ate a bananaD) He lived in the country
What does "well" mean in "I wasn't feeling well"?A) A deep hole for waterB) HealthyC) LoudlyD) Quickly
Why did the narrator "stop" working so hard?A) He lost his jobB) He was too successfulC) He realized health is more important than constant workD) The doctor was angry
Where did the narrator go after the appointment?A) Back to workB) Back homeC) To the countryD) To the piano lesson
"Sometimes I really should stop working so hard" - The word "sometimes" indicates:A) Every dayB) At no timeC) Occasionally/At timesD) On Wednesdays only

unit: Unit 4: Never too Late to Start again
question: Where was the girl born?A) In a big cityB) In a small town far away from the cityC) On a farm in DongheD) In a doctor's office
What was the girl's talent?A) Playing soccerB) Singing songsC) DrawingD) Cooking
What season is associated with "red leaves"?A) SpringB) SummerC) FallD) Winter
What was the girl's injury?A) She hurt her kneeB) She hurt her right handC) She hurt her backD) She hurt her shoulder
Why did the parents try to "fog" the situation?A) They were confused themselvesB) To keep her from being discouragedC) Because it was a cloudy dayD) They were trying to hide a secret
How did the girl act when "fronting" her parents?A) She cried openlyB) She put on a smile and tried to act happyC) She refused to speakD) She drew pictures of her pain
What was the old man doing in the park?A) Painting a sceneB) Playing with a kitten and singing a songC) Sledging down a hillD) Reading a newspaper
What was the old man's former job?A) A farmerB) A keeper in the local soccer teamC) A nurseD) A teacher
How did the keeper get injured?A) A player kneed him down during a matchB) He fell from a treeC) He was in a car accidentD) He was born with it
How old was the "keeper"?A) FiftyB) SeventyC) FifteenD) Eighty
What "sweet smell" did the old man enjoy despite his injury?A) The smell of fresh coffeeB) The smell of flowersC) The smell of fresh soilD) The smell of baked bread
What did the old man mean by life "souring"?A) Life becomes too shortB) Life becomes difficult or unpleasantC) Life tastes like a lemonD) Life stops moving
What does "Thus" indicate in the third paragraph?A) A contrast B) A time sequenceC) A reason or resultD) A location

What was the girl "sure" of at the end of the story?A) That she would never draw againB) That her parents were waiting for dinnerC) That she would become a soccer playerD) That she would move to the city
What did the girl decide to start practicing again?A) Using chopsticksB) Playing with kittensC) Using her left hand for soccerD) Drawing red leaves
What was the girl "wearing" on her face when she headed home?A) A maskB) A look of sadnessC) A smileD) Makeup
The word "ready" in "ready yourself for the journey" is used as a:A) NounB) AdjectiveC) VerbD) Adverb
What does "care" refer to regarding the doctors and nurses?A) WorryB) Medical treatment and attentionC) A specific job titleD) Shyness
"First in her family to be so artistic" - The word "first" means:A) The most importantB) The beginning personC) The fastestD) The winner

What is the "So What?" (message) of this unit?A) Soccer is more dangerous than drawingB) It is never too late to start again and find new ways to be happyC) Old men are the best teachersD) Small towns are far from the city
Who were the owners of the farm?A) Lily and her motherB) Jake and his fatherC) John and his papa, EricD) The guide and his family
How large was the farm?A) Fifteen acresB) Seventy acresC) Nine acresD) Thirteen acres
What was the "agreement" between John and Eric?A) To sell the farmB) To work together every dayC) To buy a new tractorD) To move to the city
What brought John "joy"?A) Working as a farmer with his fatherB) Receiving visitors in MayC) Cleaning the messD) Building cream mountains
What was special about this farm compared to "other" farms?A) It had many animalsB) It had flowering plants all year roundC) It was located in the desertD) It was owned by a librarian
What did "coating" the plants involve?A) Painting them for a sceneB) Covering them for protection in winterC) Giving them a shot for healthD) Washing them with soda
What did the "shine" refer to?A) Sunlight on the soilB) The light on the faces of visitorsC) A polished tool setD) The silver snow on a peak
How had the cherry trees been "classed"?A) By their priceB) By their sizeC) By their different blooming timesD) By the color of their wood
Why were some tourists called "selfish"?A) They didn't pay for the visitB) They snapped twigs for their own enjoymentC) They ate all the bananasD) They stayed too long
What did John do after the tourists left?A) He closed the farm foreverB) He gave the farm a thorough checkC) He planted new seedsD) He went back home to HsinChu
What "clean" was required?A) A quick wash of the toolsB) A thorough cleaning of the mess left by touristsC) Cleaning the soil off the bootsD) Painting the house

What was Eric's advice about doing what is "right"?A) Stop doing it if it becomes unpleasantB) We shall not stop because of something unpleasant along the wayC) Only do it if most people are selfishD) Do it only for the joy it brings
What does "On the whole" mean in Eric's speech?A) Looking at a single hole in the groundB) Generally/Considering everythingC) Only a small partD) Without any agreement
What does "yet" mean in the phrase "thirteen acres, yet taking good care..."?A) AlreadyB) However/StillC) SoonD) Never
What "scene" did John and Eric create together?A) A beautiful and hardworking farm environmentB) A fight about the touristsC) A movie about historyD) A party for the villagers
"Holing the ground" refers to:A) Fixing a boatB) Digging holes for plantingC) Cleaning the TwigsD) Making a path for tourists
The "history" of the family's farm was described as:A) ShortB) BoringC) RichD) Sad
Why were thousands of people visiting the farm?A) To view various types of blossomsB) To buy fruit from the farmerC) To see the animalsD) To study history
In "a good clean of all the mess," "clean" is used as a:A) VerbB) AdjectiveC) NounD) Adverb

What is the "So What?" (message) of this unit?A) Selfishness is common among touristsB) Do not let the bad actions of a few stop you from doing good for the majorityC) Cherry trees should only be planted in springD) Fathers and sons should always work on farms
Why was Lily's father away?A) He was on a boat raceB) He moved to HsinChuC) He was in a fightD) He was away for work
What "wish" did Lily have every year?A) To win a medalB) To see her father on ChristmasC) To own a camelD) To go to the desert
What did Lily enjoy reading from her father?A) NewspapersB) Maps of the villageC) Letters about the desert and camelsD) History books
What competition took place at the end of every year?A) A soccer matchB) A swimming lessonC) A boat-racing competitionD) A horse race
How was the weather one "early" morning?A) Hot and sunnyB) Very coldC) Rainy and cloudyD) Warm and breezy
What happened to the boat in the morning?A) It was painted English blueB) It was stolen by a camelC) It was groundedD) It was lost in the desert
What "look" did Lily have on the day of the race?A) SadB) ConfidentC) NervousD) Angry
What "beat" faster during the race?A) Their heartsB) Their drumsC) The clockD) Their wings
How was the number "Eleven" written on the boat?A) On a cardB) In big English lettersC) In small blue inkD) In Chinese characters
What "victory" did Lily share with her family?A) Winning a soccer gameB) Winning the boat race as a teamC) Catching a camelD) Flying a plane
Who was the "last" to arrive at the race?A) The other teamB) The nurseC) The pilotD) Lily's father
What was the "true taste" of victory according to Lily?A) Banana cakeB) Being better than the othersC) Soda and piesD) Winning as a team and sharing with family
What "lighted up" their family's memories?A) A fire in the desertB) The story of the Christmas victoryC) A yellow lampD) The sun rising in the east
What "note" did Lily make after the race?A) That victory is about the team and familyB) That winning is all that mattersC) That she needs to study EnglishD) That the boat was too heavy
Where was Lily sitting when she thought about the victory?A) Behind the deskB) On the boatC) In the waiting roomD) Under an oak tree
What does "grounded" mean in the context of the boat?A) Painted on the groundB) Based on a true storyC) Flown in the airD) Stuck on the land or shallow water
No longer sad - The word "no" means:A) A little bitB) Not any/NoneC) Very muchD) Perhaps
Lily's father was away "for" work - "for" indicates:A) TimeB) LocationC) MethodD) Purpose/Reason
Early in "early morning" is an:A) AdverbB) AdjectiveC) NounD) Verb
The plane did not "land" on time - "land" means:A) SoilB) A countryC) To arrive on the ground from the airD) A farm
Who did Lily live with?A) Her fatherB) Her mother and two dogsC) John and EricD) Crystal
What were the dogs' names?A) Lily and BellaB) Bella and JakeC) John and MaxD) Max and Bella
When did Lily "rise" from her bed?A) At noonB) Just as the first light touched the skyC) At sunsetD) At eleven sharp
What "date" had Lily marked in her diary?A) Her birthdayB) The village fairC) A doctor's examinationD) A soccer match
What could Lily try "free" at the fair?A) Horse ridesB) Various foodsC) Cakes and piesD) Reading the newspaper
How was the mother's cake described?A) Heavy and brownB) Fluffy, creamy, and fat-freeC) Salty and dryD) Small and expensive
When did the mother "correct" Lily?A) When she was lazyB) When things seemed to get worse during bakingC) When she forgot to water plantsD) When she was late
What "cover" story did Lily read?A) A story about a horseB) The Grand Fair announcement on the newspaperC) A story about a white-haired girlD) A poem by Tommy
How often did the "Grand Fair" happen?A) Once a monthB) Once a yearC) Every WednesdayD) Every two weeks
How did the "hours" pass during baking?A) They went slowlyB) They flew by as they worked togetherC) They were boringD) They were too long
What "tomorrow" was Lily excited for?A) Her first day of schoolB) The fair dayC) A trip to HsinChuD) A visit to the farm

What was the "So What?" (hope) of Lily's childhood memories?A) That they would help her become a bakerB) That they would last a lifetimeC) That she would move to a grand cityD) That she would buy a horse
Perhaps she thought she would win a prize - "perhaps" means:A) CertainlyB) Maybe/PossiblyC) NeverD) Always
What "worse" situation did they fear during baking?A) Running out of flourB) The cakes becoming ruined or failingC) The dogs eating the piesD) The fair being canceled
The word "beautiful" describes Lily and what else?A) The newspaperB) The sights around the villageC) The fat in the foodD) The horse races
What "two" animals did Lily care for?A) Two horsesB) Two dogsC) Two frogsD) Two kittens
Long walk - The word "long" describes:A) A period of timeB) The distance of the walkC) Lily's hairD) The newspaper headline
Watering the plants - In this context, "watering" is:A) A nounB) An action/verbC) An adjectiveD) A preposition
Who gave the "best advice" according to the word list?A) The fatherB) The motherC) The keeperD) The doctor
Grand in "Grand Fair" suggests the fair is:A) Small and quietB) Large and impressiveC) Old and dustyD) In the country
What was Crystal's hair color?A) YellowB) WhiteC) PurpleD) Brown
How did Crystal prefer to spend her time initially?A) In a large groupB) AloneC) In the city centerD) In a school
Who was Crystal's friend in the backyard?A) A little kittenB) An old tall oak treeC) A boy named JerryD) A dog named Max
What "east" event did Crystal watch?A) The sunsetB) The sun riseC) A bird flyingD) A plane landing
What "clouded" the sky in her dream/real life?A) A dark shade of grayB) A purple balloonC) A large kiteD) A white cloud
What was "served" on the big-size table in the dream?A) Bananas and sodaB) Cola and plates of piesC) Bread and waterD) Yummy meals
What does "mothered with care" mean?A) Born on a WednesdayB) Cared for and raised with loveC) Painting a picture of a motherD) Leaving home early
What "key" part did Crystal play in the dream?A) She was the cookB) She was a key part of the groupC) She was the主席 (chair)D) She was the nurse
What did Crystal "pocket" in the dream?A) A penB) A pieC) A keyD) A bell
What "bell" sound woke Crystal up?A) A church bellB) A dream/real ringing soundC) A car hornD) A school bell

What was the "So What?" (transformation) for Crystal?A) She realized dreams are better than realityB) Stepping out and social curiosity lead to inner growthC) White hair is more beautiful than yellow hairD) Car-pooling is a good way to save money
Crystal's mother worked as a:A) FarmerB) Cook at a local restaurantC) Nurse at a doctor's officeD) Librarian
What did "weathered" describe in the story?A) The temperature outsideB) The appearance of the tree after wind and rainC) Crystal's hair colorD) The taste of the pie
Reason in "She couldn't reason why" means:A) CauseB) Logically understand/deduceC) Speak/ArgueD) Fight
What "soul" means in the context of the story?A) The bottom of a shoeB) Inner spirit/feelingsC) A personD) A type of music
What did Crystal "tie" her hair with at the end?A) A penB) A beautiful bowC) A piece of stringD) A hat
What color dress was Crystal wearing for her outing?A) WhiteB) PurpleC) BrownD) Yellow
Step out - The word "out" means:A) Inside the houseB) To the exterior/away from homeC) Towards the sunD) Under the tree
Why was the car "serviced" early?A) It was brokenB) To be ready for the trip to townC) To sell itD) Because of the rain
Live music refers to:A) Music about living thingsB) Music performed in person/real-timeC) Recorded music from the cityD) Loud music
What was John's original skill?A) Baking cakesB) Climbing mountain peaksC) Professional dancingD) Farming
When did the accident happen?A) May 1stB) Third of MarchC) Last fallD) Every Saturday
Who saved John after his fall?A) A professional dancerB) Soldiers stationed thereC) A nurse from the cityD) His future wife
What could John build "inside" the bakery?A) A wood tableB) A cream mountain on a cakeC) A stone landmarkD) A set of tools
What "color" was the snow on the real mountains?A) WhiteB) SilverC) BrownD) Gold
Who was Helen before she became a baker?A) A doctorB) A professional dancerC) A teacherD) A cook
What "stop" happened to Helen's dancing life?A) A bus stopB) A complete halt due to an accidentC) A temporary breakD) A new station
Why was their marriage described as "such a good match"?A) They were both richB) They had shared experiences and hope for lifeC) They both liked silver snowD) They were both from HsinChu
What "waste" did they avoid?A) Wasting foodB) A waste of time letting emotions affect themC) Wasting money on cakesD) Wasting wood
How did they move through the "woods"?A) They walked fastB) They ran slowlyC) They drove a carD) They climbed
Direct in "direct greeting" describes the greeting as:A) RudeB) Straightforward/ImmediateC) LateD) Indirect

What was the "So What?" (metaphor) of their life together?A) Baking is safer than climbingB) They kept "climbing" and "dancing" through the challenges of life togetherC) Dancing in a bakery is funD) Soldiers should always help climbers
What "wants" did they share?A) A desire for new shoesB) Shared basic needs and life goalsC) A want for more moneyD) A want to move to the city
Stationed refers to the soldiers being:A) At a bus stopB) Assigned/Located at a postC) Making a cakeD) Running through the woods
Such in "such a good match" means:A) OnlyB) Very/To that degreeC) NoD) Which
What "short" thing did they realize about life?A) Life is short, so they shouldn't waste time on negativityB) The mountain was shortC) The cake was too shortD) The season was short
What "laugh" attracted John's attention?A) A loud, rude laughB) A charming laugh from HelenC) A laugh from a soldierD) A funny sound from the radio
Seasons changed, representing:A) The weather outside the bakeryB) The passage of timeC) A new type of cakeD) A new dance move
Third refers to which date?A) The third of MayB) The third of MarchC) The third SaturdayD) The third peak
Inside - John found new interest inside the:A) MountainB) BakeryC) HouseD) Car
Who did Max live with?A) His parentsB) His auntieC) A group of crowsD) A professional doctor
Where was the auntie's house relative to Max's room?A) UpstairsB) DownstairsC) In the city centerD) In the next village
How many "buried friends" did Max have?A) FifteenB) More than twentyC) Exactly nineD) Thirty
What "rule" did the house have?A) No noise in the kitchenB) Treat others with love and not with hateC) Always study on WednesdaysD) No animals allowed inside
What "juice" was in Max's cup?A) Sweet sodaB) Sour juiceC) Warm milkD) Salt water
What "lesson" were the other children taking?A) A math lessonB) A swimming lessonC) A poetry lessonD) A nature lesson
At what time did Max arrive home?A) Noon sharpB) Six sharpC) Eight o'clockD) Midnight
What "price" was the auntie's house described as?A) ExpensiveB) Reasonably-pricedC) FreeD) Overpriced
What "nature" observations did Max write in his notebook?A) Prices of snacksB) Observations about trees and animalsC) Names of his classmatesD) Recipes for juice
What "sharp" time did Max's auntie expect him back?A) At sunsetB) Dinner time/Ready timeC) Six o'clock sharpD) Noon
May I go out? - In this sentence, "May" is a:A) MonthB) Modal verb for permissionC) Girl's nameD) Noun
Toying with the pen means:A) Drawing a toyB) Fiddling/playing with the pen idlyC) Buying a toy at the storeD) Breaking the pen
What was the "So What?" (dream) of Max's journey?A) To be a farmerB) To be a real wildlife expertC) To move to the cityD) To open a juice store
What "heat" did Max feel?A) From a kitchen fireB) The heat of the noon sunC) From a feverD) From a cup of tea
Between describes the village's location as:A) Inside a forestB) Between rolling hills and dense forestsC) Near the seaD) Far from nature
What "body" did Max bury?A) A human bodyB) An animal's bodyC) A doll's bodyD) A plant's body
Pool - The children were in a:A) Swimming poolB) Billiard poolC) Pool of water in the woodsD) Pool of ideas
Keep it up - Max said this to himself to mean:A) Holding a pen highB) Continuing his effortsC) Staying awakeD) Keeping his notes
Kitchen - Max was greeted by a dinner in the:A) WoodsB) KitchenC) StoreD) Bedroom
Guess - Max said "I guess I can be..." meaning:A) He was sureB) He supposed/believedC) He was asking a questionD) He was lying

unit: Unit 11: The Poetic Journey of a Young Boy
question: How old was Tommy?A) NineB) ElevenC) FifteenD) Thirteen
What "ease" did Tommy write with?A) Great difficultyB) Natural ease and talentC) A lot of help from his motherD) Very slowly
Where did the gathering take place?A) Inside a factoryB) At the town commonC) On a boat numbered elevenD) In a school classroom
How many poems did Tommy write in total?A) ElevenB) SixC) NineD) Two
What did Tommy do to his nervousness?A) He kept it insideB) He downed it (overcame/swallowed it)C) He wrote a poem about itD) He ran away
Peopled with guests means the place was:A) EmptyB) Filled with peopleC) QuietD) Scary
What "spirit" did the poems speak of?A) Fear and ghostsB) The town's trials and triumphsC) A nature lover's journeyD) The spirit of Christmas
Even though - In the text, "even" is used for:A) Making things flatB) Emphasis (despite being nervous)C) Counting numbersD) Leveling a desk
Last - When he finished reading, "last" means:A) PreviousB) Finally/At the endC) Most recentD) To endure
What "word" weaving did Tommy do?A) Sewing letters onto a hatB) Arranging and connecting words into poetryC) Printing names on stonesD) Spelling English letters
What "worse" condition was mentioned in the poems?A) Bad weatherB) The worst times/trials of the townC) Tommy's voice getting worseD) A lack of food
Nosing around - What were other boys doing?A) Touching their nosesB) Searching/Snooping around the playgroundC) Writing poetryD) Playing with a kitten

What was the "So What?" (message) of Tommy's experience?A) Poetry is better than toy gunsB) Sharing one's art is a powerful way to bring people togetherC) Eleven-year-olds are very talentedD) Nervousness can be downed with a cup of coffee
This in "From this experience" refers to:A) Writing a letterB) The gathering and public readingC) Playing soccerD) A dream he had
Stay - The community believed in:A) Leaving townB) Staying together and supporting one anotherC) Staying at home aloneD) Staying in school
Ease is a:A) VerbB) NounC) AdjectiveD) Adverb
Down - In "He downed his nervousness," "downed" means:A) To go to a lower placeB) To overcome/suppressC) To fall overD) To look down

unit: Unit 12: Rising up High in the Sky
question: What was the festival about?A) KitesB) Hot air balloonsC) AirplanesD) Boats

unit: Unit 13: Acts of Kindness by a Mother and Son
question: Where did the mom and son live?A) In a busy cityB) In a tiny rural village in the westC) On a large farm in the eastD) In HsinChu center

Since the incidents - "Since" means:A) BecauseB) From that time forwardC) BeforeD) Never

unit: Unit 14: A Cop and a Boy
question: How old was Jack, the cop?A) FiftyB) EightyC) FifteenD) Seventy
